captions.text: It’s something that every young player dreams of when they’re growing up.
I didn’t really  dream of it until I thought it was realistic.
When you get the phone call and when you see it on television, and you’re seeing that you’re involved, it’s great.
It doesn’t really matter how many caps you’ve had, I think they still have the feeling of when they put the shirt on…it’s a great feeling inside you know.
I’ve always wanted to play for England ever since I’ve played football, from four, five, six.
But when I thought it might become a reality is when, at the back end of my first season at Arsenal
and to be in the under 21s squads was still a massive deal for me at that time.
To be called up for the seniors was a dream come true.
For now I’m work-in-progress.
I understand I’m not a complete player and you know I’m gladly doing the work
because I understand I need to improve.
In terms of the manager he gives you negatives and postives
which is what you need.
You need the truth, you need people that aren’t around you all the time to tell you the naked truth.
And when you get that it humbles you and it makes you realise that, look I need to improve on this and I’m going to do the work.
I found out on the day of the game that I was going to play
so I didn’t really have time to be in a set mental state.
It was great to see that I’d be in the starting eleven because I’ve never had the opportunity to start for England before.
You get underneath the tunnel and you go underneath the stadium
and you see the fans to the left and you ‘re thinking  well the fans are here, they’re making a bit of noise.
To go in the dressing room,
I saw my sleeve and I just couldn’t wait to put it on to be honest.
You have to love the pressure, you have to want the pressure,
you have to understand that to be successful you have to deal with it. You have to embrace it.
Welcome to you all to Wembley Stadium for an international between England and the Republic of Ireland.
Tonight’s England line-up shows six changes from the last game,
Danny Sturridge gets his first England start on the back of an excellent second half of the season.
22 years since the two nations met at the old Wembley.
28 years since England last defeated their opponents tonight.
Good persistence there from Daniel Sturridge…
Sturrridge…
…and it falls to Lampard. 1-1.
Will Daniel Sturridge be travelling to Brazil or is he ruled out of that game, Roy?
No he’s ruled out of the game unfortunately.
The good news is that there’s no break or fracture but there’s obviously some other damage.
But it’s like everything else, every time a player can’t take part it’s an opportunity for somebody else.
It’s an amazing country, especially Rio, the city, is unbelievable.
Our hotel is just over the side of the road
and I’ve been looking out my window onto the beach.
People are on here playing until nine o’clock at night, you know,
I’ve seen people playing in the street: They’re very experimental, and a lot of flair.
It does make you want to try stuff.
They’re just doing it for a laugh yet their tricks and their skills are probably a lot better than a lot of professional footballers.
My dad played for England and was a footballer
and in my eyes he was just my dad he was no-one special.
So I thought if he can do it, why can’t I do it?
So, you know, that’s just being young and naive I guess.
To be able to come to places like,
to places like this and represent your country is unbelievable.
In any walk of life, never mind football, you’ve always got to be appreciative of the opportunities you get.
And I think you’ve always got to have self-belief
but you can never let that self-belief be overtaken with two much arrogance
because you’ve got to realise that anyone can take your place at any moment.
Well here comes Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain.
Not exactly the same stadium that his father played in
He left Rio with a win on his CV…
…for a proud family double.
Oxlade-Chamberlain…
Rooney…
And what an equaliser, and it is Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain
It’s all a bit of a blur,
it’s an unbelievable feeling and it’s a great moment for myself.
It’s something I’ll never forget and I’m sure my family will be happy with that as well.
The most important thing is that I was able to come on and make some sort of contribution to the team.
I would have loved to have been there but something like this isn’t going to hinder me.
I’ve got faith in my body to be able to recover
The most important thing is to be going to the real thing, the real deal.
You never know what the future holds, but I’m looking forward to hopefully being on that plane.
Everyone was just saying, you know, we need to get back here next year.
Imagine this, times 100
To see how passionate everyone is and how busy it’s going to be.
So, no, it’s definitely something we’re all striving for.

title: England Matters - Episode 1: Daniel Sturridge & Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain
